> [gitcentermobile](#comment_11_1BDzk7UPg7TeTu8gdY5eefwKKRyu4yWpXo): All that computers can implement. I've updated the FAQ just in case.

How will the ZeroNet client know which elliptic curve or other crypto an address is using?

> [gitcenter](#comment_482_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): It just tries different cryptographies until it founds one that works.

That's not a good solution ... here are some numbers one could use in the addresses:

https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/8bbeaaa4fc12f8b00fbea4dc649ef74b59f73b17/crypto/objects/obj_mac.num

Or use your own numbering system. For example secp256k1 = 0,  curve25519 = 1, and on.
In general I'm not sure what the benefit would be of supporting multiple asymmetric ciphers and its implementation should not be rushed.

> [gitcenter](#comment_483_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Why is it not good?

It's just much better idea to have a byte dedicated to the cipher that's being used so you don't have to try all the ciphers that are implemented.

But again, I'm not sure what the benefit is here.
